name: Color token
htmlBanner:
Color tokens

Color creates meaning and communicates hierarchy, state, and brand. Momentum color palette is timeless, modern and vibrant, like our brand personality.

How To Use.html:
How to enable token library

Step 1.

Access the ‘Team library’ modal by clicking the Library icon.

Step 2.

Navigate to the ‘Webex Suite Apps’ tab to browse available shared libraries.

Step 3.

Find applicable theme libraries (💎 Theme - Dark / 💎 Theme - Light UI) and click ‘Add to file” button. Once enabled, the button will appear as ‘✔️Added’.

How to apply theme tokens

Step 1.

Select the element that you’d like to apply color tokens.

Step 2.

Search a style icon to reveal list of color tokens.

Step 3.

Search a token by typing the sentiment or usage of the element. Then click it to apply.

Step 4.

Once applied, you will see the mapped tokens.

How to swap themes

Step 1.

Click library icon to open the library modal.

Step 2.

View a list of all libraries which have styles and components used in your file. Select the token library. (💎 Theme - Dark / 💎 Theme - Light UI.

Step 3.

Click Swap library at the bottom of the modal.

Step 4.

Use the Choose library field to select a library. Choose the token library to swap. 💎 Theme - Dark <-> 💎 Theme - Light UI.

Step 5.

You will see all matching color style and effects with the box next to the asset is checked. If no matching styles or components are found, the box is unchecked and you'll see a None found message.

Step 6.

Click Swap library to replace the theme from your selected token library. Note that library swap would override every instance in your file, so leave unchecked the colors that you’d like to preserve.

How To Read.html:
Token naming structure

Knowing how to read token names will make it easier for you to find the right token when you're working on designs or code. The name of a design token describes its usage, and each part of the name tells you something about how it's meant to be used.

  • Sentiment.Usage.Fixed (Optional).Prominence (Optional).Interaction (Optional)

Sentiment

Sentiment indicates the meaning or role of the color. By using it, designers and developers can reduce the superstition about color design and systematically manage color.

Usage

Usage refers to where the token is applied in the UI, whether it's a background, text, border, or another property.

Based on where component sit on, we broke down usage into 4 categories: background, surface, content, and border.

Background

Background tokens are used for the main app background and content area. For mobile, use mobile background tokens for the top bars and button tabs.

Desktop & Web OX

Mobile (iOS)

Surface

Surfaces define container areas, setting them apart from the background and other on-screen elements. Components like cards, dialogs, containers, banners, and lists utilize surface colors.

Unlike other sentiment colors, the neutral palette comprises four surfaces designated by their roles: primary, secondary, tertiary, and overlay.

Primary

Used for containers that sit on the 2nd column.

Secondary

Used for containers that sit on the content area and global search.

Tertiary

Used for components which appears in a layer above other content; dialog, toast, menu, pop-over.

Overlay

Used for backdrop or overlay effect.

Content

Content refers to on-surface instances like text (icons), buttons, controls, indicators (tags, labels, presence, avatars), and illustrations. Each element employs appropriate tokens.

Text/Icon
Button
Control
Indicator
Illustration

Border

Border tokens are applied to outlines of component and dividers.

Prominence

Prominence indicates the visual hierarchy, highlighting how much an element stands out visually. It emphasizes the contrast a color has against the background.

Momentum incorporates three ordinal scales for element prominence. Please note that prominence is optional and can be excluded if not needed.

Importance

primary

secondary

tertiary

  • Used when elements have a clear hierarchy in between.
  • Used for background, text, surface, and buttons.
Strength

strong

bold

default

moderate

subtle

  • Range from weak to strongest.
  • Used for borders.
  • Default passes minimum AA contrast requirement.
Numeric

0

1

2

3

4

  • Used when no relation or no-hirearchy in between elements.
  • Used for surfaces (tertiary, overlay), illustrations

Interaction

Interaction communicates the states of interactive elements. Note that interaction is optional, and can be excluded for non-interactive components.

Focus effect

There is no dedicated token for Focus State. Instead, select the Focus Effect to components once the theme token library is enabled.

For full transparency surfaces, add a 0.01% white/black fill (#FFFFFF in dark/#000000 in light)to components. Make sure to check "Clip content" in design panel.

Color Tokens.html:
What are color tokens?

Color Tokens are the single source of truth for all colors used in Webex Brand. They allow a designer or developer an understanding of how or when to apply our palette and what options are available.

With color tokens, our visual language evolves, changes can be made once across the system and products. This will deliver visual consistency and help applying colors in a reusable, and scalable way.

Types of color tokens

Currently, Momentum uses two tiers of tokens to manage color. In most cases, designers are only allowed to use Alias Tokens instead of applying Core Tokens directly.

Color tokens

Core color token is our color foundation that used in product UI. They are primitive values that does not have any associated explicit meaning or intent, and only used to be referenced for theme tokens.

🔗 Core Token Library

Alias token (a.k.a Theme token)

Alias Tokens (aka. Theme Tokens) are context-specific and reference core color tokens. They are built using semantic names that help provide an understanding on how or when the token should be used.

Note that all components should be applied to Theme Tokens.

🔗 Theme Token Library (Dark)

🔗 Theme Token Library (Light)

How to access

Additional ways to access color token libraries for designers and engineers.

In Figma

All tokens used in Momentum are in 04 - 💎 Tokens under _Momentum Design System. To use token in your working file, you need to enable the respective token file by accessing the Team Libraries.

🔗 All Token libraries

🔗 How to enable libraries

For engineering

On the engineering side, we use the Momentum Design mono-repository on GitHub as the single source of truth for all Momentum Design-related resources. You can access all design tokens through the NPM package

🔗 Momentum Design Repository

🔗 Token NPM Package

How to request tokens

You may need to request a new color token or report a bug in the token library. Regarding all of these changes, we receive change requests through the Momentum Request Form. Figma whats wrong?

Tickets are reviewed and handled by the Momentum team in a 3-week sprint cycle.

Color.html:
Overview

Momentum colors integrate seamlessly, like the connections that Webex enables. We use color to add life, energy, and personality to our experiences. Restraining the core UI to mainly greyscale allows for the concentrated use of color when highlighting important information.

Color principles

Vibrant

Our colors express energy and synergy through uplifting shades and dynamic gradients.

Consistent

Our color system supports a uniform visual appearance across diverse products and platforms.

Accessible

Our color system ensures an adequate contrast ratio and strives to adhere to Web Content Accessibility Guidelines whenever feasible.

Momentum color anatomy

The application of our color palette ensures a unified and easily recognizable consistency across Webex's extensive range of products and interfaces. This consistency is maintained through a set of guidelines on working with the component library within the context of both dark and light themes.

Semantic

Semantic refers to the significance or purpose of a color. By employing this approach, designers and developers can dispel misconceptions about color design and methodically oversee color usage.

In conjunction with the primary blue accent, we have several semantic colors, each serving a distinct purpose within the UI.

Decorative

Mostly used for aesthetic purpose in indicators, avatar, teams, and data visualizations. These colors are less strict on WCAG 2.1 and are not to be used for typical UI designs..

Applying color

All the colors used in our UIs are designed to pass the WCAG AA requirements for minimum 3.1 contrast ratio against background.

When choosing colors, the tint between 50-60 is safe to use for non-text elements. For text elements, use up to <40 on dark, and down to >70 on light backgrounds are safe to meet 4.1 ratio.

Theming

Theming represents our inclusivity. We support the individuality and uniqueness of our users through customizations - themable interfaces and background image choices. We provide light theme and dark themes as default, alongside additional five UI themes that are available in desktop and mobile.

Default dark and light theme
Additional themes
